awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Uncovering the Role of Sirtuins in Linking Food Availability and Stress Tolerance Through Multi-Scale Signaling Networks in Mussels
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the major aims of biology is to explain how changes that occur at the sub-cellular level affect the function at higher levels of biological organization, such as organs or the whole organism. Specifically, how are changes in the expression of genes and proteins, and the concentration of metabolites of a cell, affecting the organ of which the cell is a part?  Furthermore, when do these changes in organ function affect properties of the whole organism?  Using the California mussel Mytilus californianus, we ask, when do subcellular changes in gill cells affect feeding rate or changes in muscle biochemistry affect the ability to close their shells? We aim to address these questions by collecting data from different levels of biological organization simultaneously, from the subcellular to the organ and organism levels in response to relevant environmental stressors, such as food availability, heat stress and the inhibition of signaling pathways. The investigators' expertise in comparative environmental physiology and computational mathematics will enable them to address the relevance of subcellular changes to predict organ and organism level changes using a mathematical model. The proposal has a strong training component and is centered on lowering the barriers to molecular and computational technologies and building a diverse community of young scientists in integrative organismal biology. Furthermore, K-12 resources will be developed on the physiological impacts of future environmental change that align with Common Core and Next Generation Science Standards.

The specific objective of this study is to develop quantitative, predictive models that uncover the underlying interactions/regulations among subcellular networks (transcriptomic, metabolomic and proteomic or TMP) and their effect at the phenotypes of the organ and organism in response to environmentally relevant stressors (i.e., low/high food availability and low/high body temperature), based on high-throughput experimental data, in the intertidal mussel Mytilus californianus. The experimental design will also focus on testing a possible mechanistic link between food availability and stress tolerance by inhibiting signaling pathways involving sirtuins, which are deacylases that respond to caloric restriction and stress. This proposal distinguishes itself from previous studies on the thermal physiology of intertidal organisms in that it incorporates statistical models (including regression and decision trees) to uncover the regulatory structure of the TMP networks and determine whether the resulting topology accurately predicts observed phenotypic responses measured at the organ and whole organism levels. The PIs' complementary expertise in TMP analyses, integrative biology and computational modeling will enable them to combine "omics" technologies, organismal physiology and computational approaches to advance integrative organismal biology. The PIs are planning to disseminate the modeling framework through a research coordination network (RCN) on Integrative Organismal Biology. The results will improve our ability to predict how mussels will respond to future environmental change and thereby improve our understanding of the role of mussel aquaculture in providing a secure and sustainable food resource in the future.

por.por_cntn:
The catalytic activity of proteins can be modified through post-translational modifications, additions and removals of small chemical groups that modify protein structure and efficiency. The removal of small acyl groups, important cellular metabolites, from proteins is catalyzed by sirtuins (NAD-dependent deacylaes), which have been implicated in increasing stress tolerance in organisms, probably through an improved ability to neutralize reactive oxygen species.  

We discovered that mitochondrial sirtuins (SIRT5) are changing with heat stress in intertidal mussels (Tomanek and Zuzow, 2010).  None of the other sirtuins, located in various cellular compartment, were detected and changed. We then tested which role SIRT5 has on affecting other proteins during heat stress, using SIRT5-specific inhibitors (Vasquez et al. 2017). These studies showed that SIRT5 levels vary between closely related species which differ in thermal tolerances and that sirtuin inhibition has different effects on their heat-induced proteome.  The work confirmed that sirtuins are involved in setting stress tolerance in marine organisms.  

There has been increasing evidence that greater food availability also increases stress tolerance in marine organism, especially in mussels. However, the mechanistic (biochemical) link between caloric intake and stress tolerance is unknown (Vasquez and Tomanek, 2019).  Since sirtuins are activated by NAD+, a key cellular metabolite which is itself dependent on caloric intake, we hypothesized that sirtuins are part of this mechanistic link.  

We therefore acclimated mussels to different levels of food and aerial heat stress for four weeks and then characterized their biochemical and physiological responses to an even higher heat stress at the cellular, organ (tissue), and whole organism level, focusing on gill tissue, as it is the main (filter-)feeding organ in mussels. Based on our findings that mussel proteomes, and SIRT5 specifically, follow a circadian rhythm (Elowe and Tomanek, 2021), we collected tissue samples and physiological performance measures every three hours, day and night for five days (before and after heat and inhibitor treatments).  We used sirtuin inhibitors to identify the effects of food, aerial heat stress and sirtuin inhibition on the transcriptome, proteome, and how it affected ciliary beat frequency, food (particle) velocity, respiration and filter feeding rate (May et al., 2021).  The major goal of our project was to identify the changes to the cellular (transcriptomic and proteomic) networks, and the possible cross-scale links between cellular, tissue and whole organism level effects, using mathematical modeling. This integrative approach required a high temporal resolution to connect molecular to physiological changes, resulting in a very high sample (hundreds) number for each of the simultaneous measurements.  This endeavor engaged dozens of students over two summers.

While we characterized the physiological performances and showed that sirtuins affect feeding rates (May et al., 2021), we continue to analyze our transcriptomic and proteomic data to identify the cellular level responses.  These results show for the first time that sirtuin inhibition affect a physiological (feeding) process, suggesting that sirtuins can change caloric intake and therefore their own activity levels at the level of the whole organism.

The grant supported thirty undergraduate and five graduate students (not all were paid by the grant), and two post-docs (one from an underrepresented group, both now assistant professors), in the Tomanek lab alone. Two minority undergraduates went on to obtain Masters degrees, another two minority students started at Genentech after their Masters degree.  One went on to a PhD program in immunology at Harvard.  Two other non-minority students went on to PhD programs.      

This NSF grant allowed us to provide the kind of research opportunities for undergraduates that convinced a private foundation interested in promoting STEM disciplines in the minority communities of the San Joaquin Valley, to support our outreach efforts and engage directly with these high schools to plan science summer camps and offer research opportunities for students from these communities. The foundation also started to support minority undergraduate students to do research during the academic year, specifically in our Marine Sciences program. 

The grant advanced our understanding of the integrative effects of sirtuins across scales of biological organization, advanced the careers of several minority students and launched the academic careers of two female faculty.  So far, we published seven papers closely related to the grant, with several more in preparation.  The support also allowed the PI to co-author Biochemical Adaptation: Response to Environmental Challenges from Life’s Origins to the Anthropocene (2017) with Sinauer Associates (now Oxford University Press).
